attachments.title: Release v0.10.1 by ghaskins · Pull Request #42 · hyperledger/fabric-chaintool · GitHub
attachments.text: See release commit for notes on what is included Signed-off-by: Greg Haskins <mailto:gregory.haskins@gmail.com|gregory.haskins@gmail.com>
attachments.fallback: GitHub: Release v0.10.1 by ghaskins · Pull Request #42 · hyperledger/fabric-chaintool

text: this adds full e2e support for deploying netmode chaintool apps on v1.0 architecture
(there are patches for sdk and fabric needed though, still working on upstreaming those
merged
<@U0KRRM29Z> ty
<@U0KPFAZNF> thanks for putting in the effort to upstream my fix
<@U2UNR91RB> no problem, I had a bunch of other work queued up anyway
I didn't realize REST was removed from 1.0
(Just reading release notes)
yeah, it was yanked a while ago in master, but I lagged in cleaning up the example in chaintool until now
My client generation tool is going to need some love..
Ah
you can, of course, code to GRPC instead, but I suspect its far less friction to adopt one of the SDKs
because of the crypto, etc
Are the gRPC APIs 'public' now?
well, they've always been public.  I assume you mean "stable" ? :wink:
Heh. Sure
its a good question, <@U0ULK2JPP> would know better than myself
my understanding is they are converging on the set we expect to support for v1.0
but I am not involved so not sure if more work is queued
Ideally I would have Go client packages for my chaincodes
(Ideally for me :D)
this should be theoretically possible
essentially the CLI function of the peer has an embedded golang client API
it could be ideally extricated into its own coordinate though
I see. That sounds like a good starting point
<@U0KPFAZNF> jumping in :slightly_smiling_face: … gRPC from client to peer ?
or from Chaincode to Peer ?
<@U0ULK2JPP> I did say theortically :wink:
not that I would advise this
<@U0ULK2JPP> gRPC from client to peer
sorry, yes, client -> peer
<@U2UNR91RB> was lamenting on the fallout from the removal of the REST endpoint
ah ye
yes
I think using the SDK and exposing a REST an option ?
was just noting that its theoretically possible to still code to GRPC, though its not advised
right
+1 that
and for the reasones you mentioned… all the crypto stuff and packaging that’d have to be done
better use something more easily consumable
<@U0KPFAZNF|ghaskins> uploaded a file: <https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/ghaskins/F3ZF727PV/-.js|Untitled> and commented: Just finished adding CAR support to the node SDK

file.name: -.js
file.title: Untitled
file.preview_highlight:
function packageGolangChaincode(request) {
	logger.info("packaging GOLANG from %s", request.chaincodePath);
​
	var chaincodePath = request.chaincodePath;
	var chaincodeId = request.chaincodeId;

initial_comment.comment: Just finished adding CAR support to the node SDK

text: <@U0ULK2JPP>: So you are suggesting that I build a REST frontend using the node SDK?
<@U0ULK2JPP> to that point, if things were the way Id like them, the packaging portion is a no-op :wink:
<@U0KPFAZNF> I used the wrong word (but I know what you mean) … I meant protobuf handling that goes with the gRPC
other than readfile, of course
right
im being a wiseass anyway
:slightly_smiling_face:
preaching to the choir
on a more serious note, it does all work now though
which is cool
(and this includes full FAB-678 support too
`So you are suggesting that I build a REST frontend using the node SDK?` … sounds attractive but likely have been thought out at some level
for all CC types
I’d reach to the SDK folks to see what they think of that <@U2UNR91RB>
oh so  FAB-678 is done <@U0KPFAZNF> ?
What would be the best channel for my inquiry?
well, its "done" in that I have it implemented and tested
ok
what does it mean to “deploy” ?
its not done in that the patches are not upstream yet, and I have to fix a CI problem before they can be merged
(I can go read it again if you want me to)
fabric-sdk-dev would be a start <@U2UNR91RB>
well, the meat of the changes to deployment are simple: its exactly as before except the Dockerfile can be omitted from the CodePackage and will in fact be ignored even if its included
so in the 1.0 CLI the “user” does exactly what he does today
on the backend, <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/4943/> is doing all the heavy lifting
exactly
ok
user doesnt change anything, but the CLI/SDK have been mutated to omit the Dockerfile
<@U0ULK2JPP> oh ok, -dev. Thanks
if someone runs an old CLI/SDK against the new (yet to be merged) peer, the peer will simply disregard the Dockerfile provided
so, the only group that might notice a change is anyone that had been providing a custom Dockerfile
ok
i am not aware of the scope of users that might have done this
right
i suspect its small/none
I was thinking that too
one thing I nee to do is make a nice obvious log when I detect a Dockerfile is present
to aid in the "WTF" moment that might arise if someone had been doing the custom thing
right now, i just silently plow over it if it happens to be there
actually, i should test that
i actually dont know what would happen if one is provided
i assume it would be plowed over by the TarStreamer thing, but that is a guess
basically we are talking about line 157 here: <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/4943/2/core/chaincode/platforms/golang/platform.go>
oh right, yeah, it will be ignored
the user no longer has access to the tarball that is presented to Docker
rather, its loaded as a subordinate payload
(line 162)
so codepackage.tgz could very well have a Dockerfile in it, but we will never look at it
on a related but different topic <@U0ULK2JPP>: im thinking we should clean up the whole "go binary is named after the chaincodeName" thing
and use ENTRYPOINTs
e.g. go install GOBIN=/usr/bin/chaincode && ENTRYPOINT /usr/bin/chaincode
it buys us nothing to use custom names within the container and just makes the docker interactions more complex
would also help us unify the platform drivers...e.g. java could have its own entrypoint that conforms, etc
<https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-chaintool/releases/tag/v0.10.1>
<@U2UNR91RB> that includes your fix, chaintool-env, as well as the emerging support for v1.0
but if you are using v0.6.1, stick with v0.9.2
im not maintaining compatibility, at least not until we hit v1.0
Thanks <@U0KPFAZNF>. I will be sticking with v0.9.2... Hopefully not too long.. This SDK issue is going to stick with me though..
the good news is, the SDK is much easier to work with in v1.0 than it was in v0.6
fwiw
i realize thats still a bit of refactoring if you were using REST though
I said something over in <#C25AQBS4B|fabric-sdk-dev> though, no need to divert this channel with it any more
<@U2UNR91RB> if you get a chance, think about a sane way we could incorporate a unit-test to ensure the invoker thing doesnt break in the future
or really any of the code generators would be nice to have coverage
right now its somewhat detached
i think I do have some coverage for proto.stg
but even that is a bit synthetic

<@U0KPFAZNF> I am definitely thinking about testing chaincode. I still haven't played around with the mock stub.ChaincodeStubInterface implementation yet though. I'm not sure it does what I would expect
yeah, that is probably the right line of thinking at least
:slightly_smiling_face:
even if it ends up being that we have to patch the mocks, thats fine
i.e. dont feel constrained by whats currently available in other aspects of the project
OK. I do intend to look at that stuff in the coming couple of weeks
Basically, when I start writing my next chaincode app I will try to actually get unit tests implemented. Right now everything is tested by being integrated with a peer, which is fairly clunky

In terms of ensuring that "invoker"  continues to work... I'm not sure. I guess you would want to create a test that deploys example02 and invoker into a fabric-peer container that is running --peer-chaincodedev, iirc like I showed in my original pull-request (the one I had to close :wink: ).

I have been using python scripts to do something like this with fabric v0.6.1 (chaintool v0.9.x). I would be at a disadvantage trying to do that with the node SDK. I have deliberately stayed away from JS development the last few years due to all the churn in the ecosystem
i was thinking it was simpler than that: some what to basically generate essentially the invoker stubs, and then compile them
Well, you can make sure it compiles
But that is not the same as making sure it works
e.g. "chaintool build -p path/to/invoker" and just make sure it succeeds
agreed, but its a huge improvement over what we have today
OK. Sure
right now, the .stg gets very little validation that it produces code that is actual go code, much less that it compiles
having a go-build pass over that would go a long way
Indeed
anything beyond that is gravy
<https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/5195/>
maybe I just somewhat answered my own question
we could use the invoker example in that CR 5195 UT
heh
its not tightly coupled to changes in the chaintool.git, but its better than what we have today
ideally, i would love to get this coverage in the chaintool.git::lein test suite
Would you still want to do those tests in some container to ensure that you have access to the <http://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/|github.com/hyperledger/fabric/>... packages at the right version?
thats what I was just thinking
Cool
maybe in the UT, we do that particular validation in a container so we can get the run go compiler, shim, etc
i think there are at least java libs to drive docker, so we could use java interop...or we could just exec shell commands
Maybe you can just use Go's built-in vendoring...
i.e. create a directory, examples/vendor
im open to anything at this point
so if you have an idea, run with it
Well, you may not have fabric-chaintool in your GOPATH
that is probably likely
yeah, i think this has to be done in docker
So Go's builtin vendoring wouldn't work unless the examples/ directory looked like a GOPATH (i.e. nested the examples below a src/ directory)
i think its ok to say the ut depends on docker, but if we start getting into go/GOPATH, we will run into trouble
Yes... This idea has gotten way too complicated. Just use Docker
agreed
we can use hyperledger/fabric-baseimage:$(ARCH)-0.3.0 as a stable coordinate that would have more or less the full environment
from there, pull a specific version of fabric-shim, and then run a build
Sounds right
would think that would be relatively reliable
Agreed
would also be a decent platform to get fancier with actually spinning things up down the road, if we want to get that elaborate
Right.. I was thinking that.
though probably better to wait for things like hyperledger/fabric-peer:$(ARCH)-1.0.0 than to try to build, etc
Sounds reasonable
<@U0KPFAZNF> what are your thoughts on chaintool compressing tx/query payloads?
That is, adjusting chaintool's RPC protocol to support compressed payloads.
we could, and it would be easy to do on the chaincode side, but without a client side stack (currently) I fear it would complicate clients
Indeed. I had similar thoughts.
on a related note, I was planning on dropping the base64 encoding for 1.0
i think we talked about that already though
that would have a slight compressing effect
Indeed. Base64 expands data at a ratio of 4/3
I like the idea overall, but without a client side stack it might be awkward
this is actually the first RPC/IDL system I have worked on where I wasnt generating code on both sides
it is a bit limiting, heh
In my world I am generating Go clients. So it has little effect
but related to all this, I had been contemplating having some kind of header/envelope
one of the things that envelope could carry would be encoding options, like gzip
Well, you are generating client side code, but the problem is there are three sides and only two are generated ;)
so, if we left it up to the app, it might be palatable
ah, i see what you are saying
i was confused at first, heh
you mean the cc2cc clients
Heh. Right.
Should have said consumer code.
so here are a few ideas ive kicked around
That happens to reside in a file called client-stub.go
still use "1 arg" model, but have an envelope for the payload
thats "model 1"
mode 2: use the second arg as optional
argv[2] = pb.Header
if its there, decode it
if its not, assume default options
that way, clients that dont care can stay simple
The latter sounds backwards compatible.
in there, we could have options for encoding like gzip
I would like snappy support, but yes http-style Content-Encoding
yeah, though backwards compat is largely out the window v0.6->v1.0 anyway
so i am not as worried about it
Sure. That's not really what I meant.
np, that was an aside more than anything
Just saying, fabric 1.0 might launch without this support in chaintool?
related though: if we want to do this, would be good to get it in before 1.0 goes out
because then backwards compat does matter
Ah
We are on the same page.
ah, i see what you meant
the challenge is, unlike other protocols I have designed, we dont have much opportunity to negotiate
so, if a client encodes with snappy and sets arg[2] to a chaincode compiled with an old chaintool, it wont know how to read it
Hrm. Could there be some meta negotiation query?
so, if this arg[2] thing is the way we want to go, we should at least lay the groundwork
hmm, thats a great idea actually
I already have a meta interface
not for this reason, but it could be extended
I saw that just recently.. though didn't know its purpose.
its primary purpose is it allows you to introspect a chaincode for the CCIs it supports
but it also lets you query some other metadata, like the version of your app and the compilers used
Interesting.
but theres nothing that would stop us for extending that notion to say "what encodings do you support" etc
Right!
You probably already saw this, but its covered in detail here: <https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-chaintool#metadata>
that said, I suspect the "chaintool inspect" command is broken in 1.0 because I rely on the REST endpoint
so that will need to be refactored for 1.0
but the interface is still there, regardless
its just a standard CCI, with the exception that I implicitly compile it into your app
so the backend is there, I just dont have a convenient way to query it
so, you could make a query(metadata) with no arg[2] set as a LCD
I actually didn't remember reading that section :p
figure out the encodings, and then hit the real interface encoded as you want
It took me a long time to decouple fabric and chaintool mentally.
one complication would be figuring out what to do with cc2cc
So a lot of the readme didn't make too much sense on the first read
but anyway, check it out if you have an 0.6.1/0.9.2 setup running
i think inspect will work there
I will try that at some point.
you can even download the CCIs
its kind of cool
Oh, huh. That is interesting
Maybe I could promote a chaincode out of a staging chain and into a production chain like that
Err. Nevermind
I thought you said I could download the car.
Derp
its the CCIs not the car
Is the CCI format spec defined in a way that parsers could be generated in non-jvm languages?
yeah, its protobuf
err, sorry
CAR is protobuf
there is an EBNF grammar for the CCI
so, this defines the EBNF for CCI: <https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-chaintool/blob/master/resources/parsers/interface/grammar.bnf>
though note that I also use a whitespace grammar: <https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-chaintool/blob/master/resources/parsers/interface/skip.bnf>
subtractive from the first
Oh interesting. I thought there may have been some oddities of whitespace handling.
for completeness, here is the CAR spec
<https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-chaintool/blob/master/resources/proto/car.proto>
yeah, I use the instaparse library, but most parsers I have used have some form of a whitespace/skipper function
I have some weird behavior with whitespace and inline comments (i.e. //)
I could have a bug/limitation in the grammar
I've been meaning to do more investigation and come up with small test cases.
if you find something odd, make a unit-test for it that shows the borkage
<https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-chaintool/blob/master/test/chaintool/build/test_interface.clj>
once its in that form, its easy for me to debug the parser
Excellent test_interface.clj looks like the place to go.
Thanks.
the very first test (<https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-chaintool/blob/master/test/chaintool/build/test_interface.clj#L21>) deals with comments
<@U3WM9K85R|mbaizan> has joined the channel
